sentence: Consumer stocks were broadly higher Thursday afternoon, with shares of consumer staples companies in the S&P 500 climbing just 0.1% while shares of consumer discretionary firms in the S&P 500 were up more than 0.7% today.

Bed Bath & Beyond ( BBBY ) tumbled on Thursday, sinking 14% to a session low of $21.13 a share, after the home furnishings and merchandise retailer reported a 48% reduction in Q3 net income compared with year-ago levels to $0.44 per share but still topping the Capital IQ consensus by $0.07 per share.
Revenue was little changed, slipping 0.3% from the same quarter last year to $2.95 bln, also beating the Street view by around $50 mln.

Despite the shrinking profit and sales, the company increased its quarter cash dividend by 20% over its previous distribution to $0.15 per share, payable April 17 to shareholders of record on March 16.
It also repurchased roughly 929,000 of the company's common shares through Nov. 25, paying $24 mln and leaving a $1.5 billion balance for its stock buyback program.

+ Home Depot ( HD ) was edging higher this afternoon after the home-improvement retailer earlier Thursday said it acquired The Company Store on Tuesday, paying an undisclosed amount to Hanover Direct for the online retailer of textiles and home decor products.
The transaction did not included The Company Store's five retail store locations.
+ Hasbro ( HAS ) climbed over 1% to a session high of $92.85 a share after analysts at B. Riley & Co. today began coverage of the toymaker with a Buy rating and a $108 price target.
The research shop also initiated coverage of Mattel Inc ( MAT ), starting the Hasbro rival with a Neutral rating and a $15 price target.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
